New Records: Caden Dana became the youngest pitcher in Angels history to win his debut

Dana is the first pitcher in his big league debut to go at least six innings and permit two or fewer runs at his age or younger since Houston’s Jordan Lyles on May 31, 2011, against the Chicago Cubs (20 years, 244 days). It is the first time in the American League since Joel Davis of the White Sox on Aug. 11, 1985, vs. Milwaukee at 20 years, 215 days.
Key Match Events: Taylor Ward extended his hitting streak to 12 games with a leadoff homer
Anthony Rendon provided the go-ahead hit with a two-run single in the fifth
Luke Raley homered for Seattle, which dropped to 5-4 since Dan Wilson replaced Scott Servais as manager on Aug. 22.
Pre-Game Insights: Dana, who led double A with 147 strikeouts, appeared in the MLB Futures Game in July and is considered the Angels’ best pitching prospect.
Post-Match Reflections: “That’s pretty cool hearing that,” Dana said.
Miscellaneous Highlights: An 11th-round pick in the 2022 amateur draft, Dana went 9-7 with a 2.52 ERA in 23 starts for Rocket City before being called up Friday.
Others: Bryce Miller (10-8) gave up three runs and four hits in 4 2/3 innings.
